summary: Ruby SDK does not allow multiple workflow handlers (signal, update, query) to share the same name, unlike other SDKs. This causes a RuntimeError when attempting to define handlers with identical names for different handler types.
userImpact: Ruby developers cannot implement the same handler logic for different handler types with a shared name, forcing workarounds and reducing code reusability compared to other SDKs.
rootCause: The Ruby SDK's handler decorator implementation does not allow multiple handler types to share the same name, enforcing a one-name-per-handler-type constraint that other SDKs do not have.
proposedFix: Modify the Ruby SDK handler registration mechanism to allow multiple handlers of different types to share the same name, matching the behavior of Python and other SDKs.
workaround: Use different names for each handler type (signal, update, query) even if they implement the same business logic.
resolutionDetails: The Ruby SDK was updated to allow multiple workflow handlers of different types to share the same name, bringing it into parity with other Temporal SDKs.
keyQuote: Workflow signal UpdateOrder already defined as a different handler type (RuntimeError)
